Speaker: Mr FILING
Title: Unknown
text: If I could just speak briefly obviously not on my amendments but on the government's amendments. Yesterday in the House I asked a question of the Minister for Family Services (Mr Warwick Smith), who represents the Minister for Communications, the Information Economy and the Arts (Senator Alston), about Telstra's role in relation to Internet service and Internet access provision. One of the great problems, in my view, in our telecommunications system in relation to Internet service and access provision is that Telstra in essence, in the same business as the people to whom it supplies lines to conduct their own businesses. In my view, that is a gross conflict of interest. I think that should be abolished as a matter of grave urgency .. I have an my interest in the Internet service provision and access provision industry and have made inquiries over some time about the problems associated with access to lines. Generally speaking, Telstra appears to have done the right thing. It appears to have provided lines reasonably swiftly to lAPs and they, to my knowledge, have not made substantial complaints about Telstra's slowness. Nonetheless, the fact that Telstra is in business with big pond Internet access is in itself a conflict of interest because, in essence, Telstra is providing the very same service as its competitors but they cannot do their service without Telstra providing them with lines. In my view, not only is that a conflict of interest; it is anti-competitive and in fact flouts very seriously what the coalition government would consider to be its competition policy. The Internet will be one of the major growth industry areas in telecommunications service provision. It is my view that one of the most serious impediments it could have is having a conflict of interest or an anticompetitive influence like this. It behoves the minister to do something about this matter of urgency. I was interested to hear the minister representing the minister for communications say in response to my question yesterday about how long this particular monopoly would last that he did not know. I know the minister representing the minister for communications is one of the best informt'(d people in this parliament about thetelecommunications industry. With his having been the Telecommunications Ombuds.man in the past and his being an intelligent minister who performs well, it is surprising that he was not in a position to answer this question. , I suggest that the monopoly will continue. If that is the case and the sale of Telstra ahead on the basis that Telstra enjoys what is a very substantial monopolistic role in the is, provision of Internet access service to the Australian community, I think that is a matter of great shame to the coalition government. It should not proceed .unless those sorts of issues are overcome. I know the Minister for Finance and Administration (Mr Fahey), being an advocate for greater competition, would probably agree with me, but unfortunately he is responsible for the carriage of the bill for another minister, another department. I must point out that, as the shadow minister observed in his speech, this represents also a dividend for Telstra. Telstra's monopoly in this area is a considerable asset and naturally enough the government, in trying to realise the greatest possible return from the sale of its. asset, is unlikely to withdraw that monopoly. Therefore, the government has a conflict of interest. This is one of those classic cases where a government, in endeavouring as it says to introduce wider competition into a particular market, is in actual fact restricting competition through its very own administrative or legislative arrangements in relation to Telstra. So here we have a situation where a government, committed as it says to competition policy-I will talk very soon about another aspect of competition between digital and analog networks-is going to market Telstra to the community and elsewhere with a monopoly built in-a monopoly that, in my view, is a very serious impediment to the development of Internet services in this country and something that the government ought to remedy as soon as possible.

Speaker: Mr ALLAN MORRIS
Title: Unknown
text: We are now seeing the start of the adjustments. We have now the start of what I expect will be literally hundreds of amendments to the Telstra (Transition to Full Private Ownership) Bill 1998 as the government starts to grapple and come to terms with what really is a total conflict of interest. It is selling a monopoly and trying to maximise its value at the same time as it is pretending the monopoly will do all things for all people. People in the bush who are concerned about goes their future services should be extremely concerned that the government has not moved further on these amendments today. The fact is the minister can no longer direct-a major change in government relinquishment of powers but for a price: to maximise the value-and we are now seeing some fancy footwork to try to pretend that that is not the case. This whole issue has come before us out of nowhere, without thought, without public debate and without government examination of the policy issues involved. The amendments the Minister for Finance and Administration (Mr Fahey) has moved are the first of many. The points raised by the member for Dobell (Mr Lee) regarding the real aspects of competition, who judges whom and who is responsible are the tip of a very big iceberg. The comments made by the member for Moore (Mr Filing) in terms of competing interests within Telstra and its users is another huge iceberg. Today the convergence of technologiesand not simply physical technologies but software and educational technologies-is so profound that it will transform society as we know it over the next 30 or 40 years. In the middle of that will be Telstra and a government trying in the years ahead to come to terms with what it is doing right now: laying the framework that will have massive implications for decades to come. We inherited an organisation built up over almost a century by the Australian people, adapting and changing as it went, staying at pace with the world-and, in many cases, in front of the world because of our geographical problems. We are, in a moment, at the stroke of a pen, transforming it. The thought that that involves and the implications of that are so profound that to be dealing with it in this way is disgraceful. These amendments are simply a minuscule attempt to modify, but they also give the government some pretence that it actually understands the issues. Those Australians who have helped build Telstra-and that involves every Australianall own Telstra. Government assets vary in terms of access but, unlike other assets, we all use a telephone. The discussion by government members of the idea that there is somehow some competition about who sells the most and when has been a farcical one. I think the points being made in terms of Internet are simply a very small part of what the government is doing now with no public debate, with no understanding of either the technology or its implication. For the convergence of the technologies, the capacity to bundle and the implications for this whole issue one only has to look at the impact of Microsoft in the United States and at the current legal action between Microsoft and the American Justice Department and the implications for market power, market dominance and how that works. Mr Hockey- Mr Deputy Speaker, I raise a point of order. I have got to put him out of his misery. It goes to relevance. What the member is speaking about it totally irrelevant.

Title: Unknown
text: I move amendments Nos 1 to 4: (1) Schedule 1, page 7, after item 3 (after line 22) insert: 3A Section 360 Repeal the section. (2) Schedule 1, page 7, after item 3 (after line 22), insert: 3B Section 361 Repeal the section. (3) Schedule 1, page 7, after item 3(after line 22), insert: 3C Section 362 Repeal the section. (4) Schedule 1, page 7, after item 3 (after line 22), insert: 3D Section 363 Repeal the section. The purpose of these amendments is to repeal the provisions in the Telecommunications Act which force the closure of the analog mobile network. In 1992 the then minister for communications, former Senator Bob Collins, entered into a contract with Vodafone which has the following provisions. The first is that the analog network be closed down on 31 December 1999, and this appears in clauses 3.3 to 3.7 of the contract. The second is that the minister may make variations to the law for the purposes of protecting or promoting the interests of consumers of telecommunications services, in clause 3.2(c), or for the purposes of providing emergency services, in clause 3.2(e). On 4 May 1993 that contract was tabled in both houses as a disallowable interest. No-one moved that it be disallowed so it was, in effect, ratified by unanimous consent at the expiration of 15 sitting days. Senator Richard Alston was the shadow minister for communications at the time. He spoke 728 times in 1993. Mr Lee-How many'!

Speaker: Mr FILING
Title: Unknown
text: It was 728 times and, as far as I can see, he did not once mention analog mobile phones in any of the 728 times he spoke. On the day the contract was tabled, he asked a question about the expense claims of one of Paul Keating's former staffers. So the contribution to the debate of this shadow minister for communications on the day the mobile analog network was being put on the chopping block was to ask about the expense claims of one of the former staffers of Paul Keating. It is therefore misleading of Senator Alston to say that this is all Labor's fault. I am being fair-minded here. He had an opportunity to prevent the Labor government entering into that contract and did not take it, but that is water under the bridge. In 1993 everyone thought that digital was a great idea. In 1998 the shortcomings of digital are plain for all to see. The government has failed to take the only course that would solve this problem, and that is to repeal sections 360 to 363 of the Telecommunications Act and sit down with Vodafone to negotiate an end to the no-analog clause of the contract. The government's failure to do this is nothing short of irresponsible. The longer it is left the more expensive it will be because Vodafone is building more and more network all the time. Mr Hockey-Hear, hear!

Speaker: Mr FILING
Title: Unknown
text: They are in your electorate, obviously. On 11 March the coalition took office. It should have acted promptly to bring Vodafone's contract to an end because by then anyone who knew anything about telecommunications knew that the digital systems coverage was hopelessly inferior to that of the analog system. On 1 July the Telecommunications Act 1997 became law. Sections 360 to 363 were essentially the same as clause 3.6 of the Vodafone contract. If these sections are repealed it will permit Telstra to continue operating the AMPS network as long as it wishes. It will also permit others, including Vodafone, local shire councils and entrepreneurs, to est!lblish analog base stations. There is great interest in doing this, Mr Deputy Speaker Dondas. You would know that, coming from the Northern Territory. It will permit Telstra to continue operating the AMPS as long as it wishes. For example, the Carrathool Shire Council wants to establish an analog base station to cover the town of Hillston and surrounding area, including 100 kilometres of the Kidman Way, the new road that will cut 200 kilometres off the Melbourne to Darwin road distance. An Australian company in Perth makes analog base stations and at present cannot sell its product in Australia because of sections 360 to 363. Repealing these sections will generate an opportunity in high tech manufacturing right here in Australia; all digital base stations to this day are imported. As I mentioned earlier in my previous contribution, it is a philosophical tenet of the coalition government to support greater competition. But here we have a telecommunications act which is anti-competitive in nature in the marketplace. We are demanding that the analog mobile phone network is allowed to continue in competition with the digital service so that people have the fullest possible choice and can make that choice as consumers to get the best possible service no matter where they live-whether they are in the middle of Sydney as is the member for North Sydney, in regional Australia as in your case, Mr Deputy Speaker, or in the electorates of those other members who represent regional areas of Australia that are so badly affected by the poor quality digital service.

The member for Moore (Mr Filing) is moving spurious amendments which seek to undermine the contractual arrangement made between the then Labor government-I note that the former minister for communications is here in the chamber-and Optus and Vodafone that by 1 January 2000 AMPS would be phased out immediately. It was a drop-dead date. It was not a phase out; it was a drop-dead date. It was a deal between the ALP federal government and Optus, Vodafone and Telstra. I can only suggest that the major beneficiary of this spurious attempt to try to extend the life of AMPS is Telstra. Why? Telstra absolutely dominate the AMPS market. Through this amendment the member for Moore is reducing competition and giving Telstra the greatest leg-up that they have had in years. He is trying to preserve the Cobb and Co. infrastructure provided by the Labor Party in 1992. It is a Cobb and Co. infrastructure because AMPS will be outdated by CDMA and by D-AMPS. The relocation of the spectrum out of analog is going to be used for new and better technology. In deference to the terrific work of the Minister for Communications, the Information Economy and the Arts (Senator Alston) in relation to this matter, on 5 February the minister announced that he would try to do everything he could within the contractual constraints provided by the Labor Party to try to preserve mobile phone communications for people who currently have AMPS and do not have digital technology. Of course, that includes an urgent review by the Australian Communications Authority, and a number of other measures that ensure that, at the end of the day, people in rural Australia who have analog and do not have digital are not left, on the drop-dead date of 1 January 2000, without mobile phone technology in their area. I wonder what the motivation is for this. Perhaps the member for Moore could answer this at another time, because he is pushing the federal government, the Commonwealth, into a protracted legal case between the Commonwealth and Vodafone because of the original pledge of the Australian Labor Party in 1992. Vodafone deliberately have not got into analog technology because of that drop-dead date. This amendment will have the single most significant impact on the value of Optus and Vodafone and it will be the greatest impediment to competition in mobile phone technology rather than our trying to create a competitive environment and ensure that people in rural Australia are getting the very best technology-the latest technology and complete technology-that delivers mobile phone access right across the nation. (Time expired)  have heard a very interesting contribution from the member for Moore (Mr Filing) highlighting a problem in the Telstra (Transition to Full Private Ownership) Bill 1998. One of the things that I would say about these .amendments is that they really highlight some of the dangers that are presented in privatising Telstra. But isn't the issue the has not been rolled out throughout Australia? I remember contributions by the member for O'Connor (Mr Tuckey), who is vocal on most things, if not all, saying how much he regretted the fact that in parts of his electorate was no mobile service at all. What the coalition says basically is, 'Look, don't worry, there is a marketplace. All these problems will get sorted out in the marketplace and you will see this miraculous roll-out of technology to give people in rural and regional Australia mobile access.' We, from a Labor Party perspective, say that sometimes the marketplace does not sort these things out; sometimes the shareholders do not actually take decisions in the national interest; and there is a legitimate role for government to ensure that no Australian is particularly . disadvantaged. The roll-out of mobile technology and the uptake by Australians has been absolutely phenomenal and we ought to talk about mums and dads missing out but, putting that aside, smal1 business and farmers in rural and regional Australia are the ones who so grievously suffer by a paucity of service. I believe that the commitment to make it exclusively GSM was a bipartisan issue. I think that is what the honourable member for Moore points out when he says that the shadow minister, Professor Ergas-I am sorry, the shadow minister, Senator Alston!-spoke more than 700 times that particular year and never once mentioned this particular issue. I regret that some of the means of redress have been removed. Indeed, the so-called technical minor amendments dealing with ministerial discretion have actually been removed from this legislation rather than providing rural and regional Australia with extra opportunities to ensure, through the parliament and through the executive government, that their needs are met. So, whilst I do not support the amendments moved by the honourable member for Moore, I think it is entirely appropriate that members on the opposition side should be allowed to move amendments. Even if these amendments do not get up, I believe he is legitimately highlighting a problem for rural and regional Australia that has been picked up in the fact that digital earlier, wider debate.

Speaker: Mr ANDREN
Title: Unknown
text: I think the House recognises that they made a dreadful mistake back in 1992 when this deal was signed with Vodafone. The Telstra there (Transition to Full Private Ownership) Bill removes the jurisdiction of the minister in relation to Telstra. It says that it would be inappropriate to retain such a power in a situation where the Commonwealth no longer holds a majority equity interest in Telstra. That goes right to the heart of this particular set of amendments, which I support strongly, because-despite what the member for North Sydney (Mr Hockey) says-these amendments are very relevant to this particular debate and this bill in fact. The relevance is clearly established in the preamble to the bill, which sets out the policy objectives and reaffirms the parliament's commitment to the comprehensive community and regulatory safeguards recently enacted in the 1997 telecommunications legislation. There must be a regulatory framework on mobiles and it should not include the abolition of the analog mobile coverage. I was accused the other night of not showing any interest in this until recent days, and the member for North Sydney graciously admitted that I had had a long interest in this and had spoken strongly during the telecommunications debate on this very analog issue. It is promised that a meaningful analog system will be maintained. That is absolutely absurd in relation to a seat like Cal are because Calare would be regarded as having an adequate digital service, according to the definitions, and in fact it does not. I get a kilometre out of Orange and the service is absolutely appalling and yet the analog system works very well. As I said in the debate last week on this particular issue, it is a service-a communications tool--of absolute necessity and it is not Cobb and Co. technology. As the member for Kalgoorlie (Mr Campbell) pointed out in his contribution, the CDMA technology available from the US now is world's best and would mesh with the existing analog system to provide an Australia-wide coverage that would be far superior to anything yet tested and on offer. Vodafone tell me that they are relying on satellite technology to cover all of Australia. They are not going to roll out digital across the length and breadth of inland New South Wales and further afield; they are relying on the satellite service. At $4,000 a handset and $4 a minute, just who will be able to access this technology? We have something in place now that does the job. The Communications Authority fact sheet tells us that they will examine each regional area which currently receives an analog service to determine whether the phase-out of the analog service would leave that area without alternative mobile coverage. Calare is one seat that would not fit under that category. It will not keep analog in an area like that. In fact, residents of areas determined by the government to retain access to the analog mobile network should be aware that analog handsets will not work outside these areas. This is a deliberate plan to cripple AMPS; it is not a plan to restore and retain services of any use in regional Australia. And Vodafone has given the game away by admitting to me that it is relying on satellite. It is not about roll out digital beyond the major lucrative markets, the regional markets and along the highways; and even there it does not work. Like television and broadcast, telephony provision is a privilege. Two wrongs, the privatisation of the Commonwealth Bank and Telstra, do not make a right. All this debate has centred around who did things first. Well, we have made mistakes. We should sit down, as the member for Moore (Mr Filing) said, renegotiate this whole analog question and, if these sections are repealed, Rylstone Kandos, which has no mobile, would be able to enter the market as an individual provider. That is real opening up of the market, using technology that Australian Defence Industries, which we are also about to flog off, makes and sells offshore but cannot sell locally. We could do it ourselves. The shire councils struggling for funds could have a revenue source if they were able to put up this technology. It is the best technology, it must remain, and this is one means of highlighting that and hopefully getting some sense in this whole debate.

Speaker: Mr LEE
Title: Unknown
text: On behalf of the opposition, I would like to outline our position on the amendments moved by the member for Moore (Mr Filing) and argued very eloquently by the member for Chifley  Andren), the member for MCPherson (Mr Bradford) and the member for Moore. It might be helpful if we all take ourselves back to 1992, when this decision was made. It was a decision made by the then Minister for Communications and Transport, Bob Collins, and it was on the advice of Austel after Austel had conducted an inquiry into what is a very complicated issue. The Austel report in 1992 made the very obvious point that we could not just rely on the existing analog mobile telephone system because Telstra owned the whole spectrum and ran the entire mobile network and that one of the advantages in moving towards digital was that you had new - spectrum you could sell off to a number of new entrants and that was the way we got competition in mobile telephony: by having Optus, Vodafone and Telstra able to have their own spectrum and able to compete with each other on mobile telephone rates. The result of that has been big reductions in the cost of mobile handsets and some reductions in the price of mobile calls, and that has benefited consumers. We are also told, and it is accurate, that there would be encryption and therefore greater privacy for telephone calls if we moved to digital. Another thing we were told is that we would get clearer calls. I think that was the one claim that was made way back in 1992 that has not been fulfilled by the technology. I am sure that the people in the gallery and in the parliament here this morning would know that it is often very difficult to get clear signals with the digital system. There are large parts of rural and regional Australia where you cannot get any signal at all and the member for Calare has highlighted some of those today. One of the concerns that we in the opposition have about the member for' Moore's attempt to put a lance through the boil of this debate is that his amendment might have the parliament exposing the public, through the government, to a very large compensation bill. The opposition would want to have a great deal more confidence about what the consequences would be before we would be prepared to support the member for Moore's amendment. The point I would make to the Minister for Finance and Administration (Mr Fahey), who is at the table, is that no doubt there is a problem out there that needs to be addressed. That is why members are raising this issue in the parliament every day. My colleague the member for Hunter (Mr Fitzgibbon) has, I know, spoken about this within the Labor Party, based on his concerns about what is going to happen when AMPS shuts down. Some of us have to remember that, if this current problem is the result of an agreement between the federal government, Telstra, Optus and Vodafone, then surely another agreement between the federal government, Telstra, Optus and Vodafone can undo any financial exposure. I would have thought that it is open to the government to say to Frank Blount, Mr Anderson and the boss of Vodafone that we need this issue resolved. Telstra can enter into some commercial negotiations with Optus and Vodafone about what payment it might make to them to persuade them to allow the analog system to continue. There is a possible solution out there if we can try to think creatively and do it in a way that does not expose the taxpayer to large sums of money. I would like to ask the Minister for Finance and Administration a question; he might take it on notice if he cannot answer it today: if of the analog system is shut down can we be assured that the current GSM digital system is able to cope with all of the customers? I have heard some speculation that, if all of the analog customers move to digital, the system would be swamped in some parts of the country. If the minister is not able to answer that on the spot today, I would be more than happy if he could agree to provide me with an answer in writing. The parliament, in debating this issue, should have some reassurance that, if we are not going to accept the member for Moore's amendment, the digital system will be able to cope with the massive needs that will be placed on it in the year 2000, especially in places like Sydney. With the Olympics, international visitors with digital phones will expect them to work in this country.

Speaker: Mr FAHEY
Title: Unknown
text: I have noted the amendments moved in respect of sections 360 and 363 by the honourable member for Moore (Mr Filing). These amendments amount to a change to what has been entered into by way of a legally binding contract by the former government, particularly with Vodafone. Such a proposal is totally unworkable. It exposes the taxpayers of Australia not only to massive compensation but to ridicule. I just wonder about the simplistic approach-the populist approachtaken by Independents to any debate. They come into this House and put up a proposal that alters legally binding contractual obligations. It gives a clear message to any investor in this country: do so at your peril. I spent some time this morning with an investor from the electorate of the honourable member for Calare (Mr Andren). I have ,known the company for some years and have had dialogue with them over many years. The thought occurred to me that if that company, which has put a massive amount of money into the electorate of Cal are, is going to be told by this parliament that the parliament may reverse its decisions on contractual obligations at the whim of a populist Independent, that company and no-one else onshore or offshore will ever again put an investment into this country. Mr Allan Morris- Mr Speaker, on a point all of order: I accept that the member for Calare has some modesty about that. That was a very nasty inference which I personally found offensive as a parliamentarian-reflecting on the motives of a person in this House. The minister should withdraw and apologise.

Speaker: Mr DEPUTY SPEAKER
Title: Unknown
text: There is no apology.

Speaker: Mr FAHEY
Title: Unknown
text: Firstly, I am making the point that when there is a decision by government that decision should have certainty. When legally binding contracts that flow from such a decision are entered into, they cannot be overturned in a way which this amendment proposes to do. The second point I want to make-and it was made very properly by the honourable member for North Sydney (Mr Hockey)-is that when it comes to technology and regional Australia, surely those who represent regional Australia would want the best technology. To suggest that we extend on analog in respect of mobile phones well into the next century condemns rural and regional Australia to second-rate technoiogy. The third point is that it is simply not practical to suggest that there is a capacity to extend on at this point when we are well dQwn the track in the changeover to digital. As I have indicated, Vodafone in particular, under the arrangements and contracts that were entered into, have simply embarked upon that technology and they would simply be taken out of business if there is an extension there. I reaffirm the point made by the honourable member for North Sydney that nothing is more supportive of Telstra's monopoly than these proposed amendments. Telstra have the monopoly in analog. The new carriers have moved into digital. The monopoly would be extended. It seems to me that every argument I have heard from the opposition and from those who oppose this bill on the crossbenches is about trying to ensure that the competition against Telstra is opened up. The regulations required that to happen as at 1 July last year. As each year and each month goes by, that will happen. Let me give a quick run down of what the Minister for Communications, the Information Economy and the Arts (Senator Alston) said by way of a press release on 5 April on the solution to the problem: Yes, government acknowledges that there are blank spots when it comes to mobile telephony in rural and regional Australia. That is being addressed, but is it being addressed quickly enough? That remains to be seen; nevertheless, the government is conscious of the need to ensure that the service is across Australia and that that service continues after the required phasing in of digital occurs as at 1 January 2000. The package released by my colleague in another place indicated that all areas of regional Australia which currently receive mobile phone coverage will continue to enjoy reasonably equivalent coverage after the year 2000. As for the elements of the package, the ACA will conduct an urgent review of the current regional AMPS service. That will be completed by 30 June 1998. (Time expired)

Speaker: Mr FILING
Title: Unknown
text: I will answer a couple of points that the Minister for Finance and Administration (Mr Fahey) has raised. The first relates to his comments about the actual technology. The argument that the technology is better, as my understanding is, in latter times has never been raised; it has always been the subject of the contract. Let me give you an example from an interview with one of the government's own experts from the ACA, the head of ACA's analog closure education program, Mr Warren Duncan. The interviewer on 3AW put to Mr Duncan that a knowledgeable caller had suggested that digital coverage would never cover the whole of Australia, that it was impossible. This is Mr Duncan's answer-the answer\of the government's own expert: That could very well be the case, but the difference really is that . . . it's because of the nature of the technology ... Analog can stretch out over quite considerable distances whereas, dependent upon where the base station is, digital may not cover the same extent . . . Those words on the service, on the technology, are from the mouth of one of the government's own experts. Here he is, damning the digital coverage when asked the question, 'Can it provide the same sort of coverage that analog could?' It was once said of the Bourbon dynasty: they learnt nothing but remembered everything. I must say that one of the great criticisms of the community about government in modem Australia is that, whenever a mistake is made by government, it either tries to cover it up or compounds the mistake by pretending that it was not a mistake in the first place. That seems to be the situation here. We have had the argument from the Minister for Finance and Administration that somehow the people who are supporting analog' phone networks are neo-Luddites, somehow wedded to sort of steam engine technology. Yet, at the cutting edge of the world's marketplace in mobile phone services in the United States, the analog network is doing very well, thank you very much. In fact, the analog network in the United States is highly competitive, cheap, and provides an excellent service. Because the United States is not as hidebound as we are to sort of leap into the first new technology that appears on the block, it actually has better digital technology that we do. The United States has the situation where its digital technology and its analog technology can go hand in hand. So you can get a phone that will roam in both types of technology-but you cannot do that here in Australia. The minister-the same minister who, in the year that analog technology was mooted for destruction, spoke 728 times, never once mentioning the analog network-was trying to pretend on a radio program that,there was, in fact, a similar sort of technology available in Australia. That is absolute rot, and he should have known that. There is another aspect to this, and that is the question of safety. Regional Australia obviously experiences considerable problems with bushfires and disasters, and all those sorts of emergencies that occur from time to time, where, because of the geography, the distances, the isolation, telephone technology is absolutely critical to personal safety. We have a situation where this government concedes that, in the event of bushfires in remote areas, you would be better off carrying two telephones, a digital and an analog, because the analog would probably give you a better chance, in an area where there is poor coverage with the digital network, of being able to communicate to ensure your own personal safety. I have had personal experience of this with fishermen in my electorate. They were persuaded by Telstra's telemarketers to buy digital; they said, 'We suggest you go for digital technology. It is exactly the same as the analog technology you've already got.' Those fishermen bought it, they paid thousands of dollars; they got out to sea and they found it did not work. Mr Deputy Speaker Dondas, you would know from your own territory that the tyranny of distance and service delivery would make the destruction of the analog network in these circumstances an absolute aberration-in fact, a neglect of duty on the part of this government to provide the best possible service availability to all citizens, no matter where they live. We live in one of the world's most remote continents, and we have the problem of distance and sparseness of population. I would have thought a government would be committed to what are called its community service obligations, its universal service obligations-those things that are quietly being smothered to death by the government as it sells off the rest of Telstra. Those community and universal service obligations include the right to access the best technology available to all Australians. That does not mean that having a fetish for one particular type of technology should deprive some Australians of their right to access that technology. (Time expired)

Speaker: Mr NEVILLE
Title: Unknown
text: I can understand that the member for Cal are (Mr Andren) may be well motivated by his desire to see that a technology exists in all parts of his electorate. But I think you have to take a broader vision of what has to happen for the future of telecommunications in Australia. We have had a history of various forms of phone technology, from the old wind-up phone, to the dial phone, to the latest handsets that can hold calls and do all sorts of things. In parallel with that, we now have digital, which is about the third technology that we have adopted with regard to mobile phones. But I think the member for Calare is not recognising that one of the things allowing mobile phones to be competitive and forcing the cost of calls down is the fact that there is competition. What he is suggesting flies in the face of the medium-term and long-term needs of Australia. We are now moving in television technology from analog to digital.

Speaker: Mr DEPUTY SPEAKER
Title: Unknown

Speaker: Mr NEVILLE
Title: Unknown
text: Ninety-four per cent of the population already has access to digital. I would have thought that the challenge was to make sure that more people had the benefit of that technology. Using again the analogy of television transmission, if we were to let analog and digital TV exist side by side indefinitely, we would be dooming Australia or the operators to $30 billion to $50 billion Of dual transmission costs. I would have thought it was sensible to phase out the analog in an orderly way, taking into account what the Minister for Finance and Administration (Mr Fahey) said, that is, protecting those areas that will not get a comparable service in the meantime, then from there moving to a more focused view on digital so that we can take on board new technologies like CDMA-I agree with thatand low-orbiting satellites. To regress to analog is like going back to the old wind-up phones; it makes no sense. Mi FAHEY (Macarthur-Minister for Finance and Administration) (12.18 p.m.)-As I was saying earlier in the debate, the government recognises that there are gaps in the service in respect of digital and that in time the six. per cent that the honourable member for Hinkler (Mr Neville) referred to will be addressed. It is a question of how quickly and the need to ensure coverage in the interim period. It is for those reasons that my colleague in another place has asked the ACA to conduct an inquiry to determine just what the current regional service is about-and regional services in particular where they receive the AMPS service-and to determine whether the phase-out would leave the area without alternative mobile phone coverage offering a quality of service and a breadth of coverage reasonably equivalent to that offered by AMPS. AMPS will be retained after 1 January in those regional areas where the review finds that there would be no reasonably equivalent coverage following the AMPS phase-out and where Telstra, Optus and Vodafone agree to the continued operation of the AMPS service. The government will, if necessary, after consultation with Telstra, Optus and Vodafone, impose additional network roll-out obligations on each of them so that in regional areas, where the review finds that there would be no reasonably equivalent coverage following the AMPS phase-out and where the three firms, Telstra, Optus and Vodafone, do not agree to continue operation of the AMPS service, those three firms will be required by government to provide reasonably equivalent coverage through other means such as GSM. The government will further consider mandating roaming between parts of the GSM network which are installed under the roll-out obligations if it is technically feasible and commercially appropriate, as this may be a practical way of reducing the cost to Telstra, Optus and Vodafone of a given expansion of the GSM range. Further, the government will require improved reporting on the quality of service and coverage from the carriers and we will develop and implement a binding AMPS phase-out plan designed to enable AMPS customers to have a smooth transition to alternative services. There is a recognition. The contract was signed in 1992. I should mention to the honourable member for Moore (Mr Filing) that it was not a disallowable instrument as referred to in his opening remarks on this question. It was not a disallowable instrument; it was tabled. In that regard the contract has been there since 1992. Contractual arrangements of ,that nature cannot be changed without drawing attention to all areas of commerce and investment in this country and路 putting them at risk and in doubt. It would make us the laughing stock of the world, let alone cause irreparable damage to our economy. The honourable member for Dobell (Mr Lee) raised the matter of the capacity for coverage, particularly in the Sydney area, with reference specifically to the demand that will be there around the year 2000 with so many other visitors and so much activity in a city like Sydney. I cannot give the answer to that. I will take it on board and ask the relevant minister in another place to deal with Evans, M. 1. that aspect and inform the honourable member in due course. There is a problem; it is acknowledged. There is a solution; it is practical. It is the only solution that is workable. The amendments that are being brought forward by the honourable member for Moore, supported by others on the cross-benches, are simply not practical or workable. I understand their concern, but the greater concern must be surely that to bring forward amendments of this nature would throw the whole process into total confusion and put at risk the commerciality of contractual arrangements in an area which is important to regional Australia and to all Australia. Also, of course, if they were successful, they would condemn regional Australia to an outmoded process, not the most modern of systems, and surely rural and regional Australia has the right to the most modern of systems. I move: That the question be now put. Question resolved in the affirmative. Question put: That the amendments (Mr Filing's) be agreed to. The House divided. [12.27 p.m.] (Mr DEPUTY SPEAKER - Hon. Speaker: Mr ALBANESE
Title: Unknown
text: I rise today to oppose this third reading of the sale of the remaining two-thirds Telstra. I do so because Telstra is one of best telecommunications providers in the world. Its connections reach 96 per cent of Australian households which all enjoy unincompanies terrupted access to the national network. also do it because I think that election promreluctant ises are important. During the debate prior to NOES the last election, the now Prime Minister (Mr Howard) said in a debate with Paul Keating, the then Prime Minister: Can I just say that we are not selling off all of Te1stra, we are selling a third. There is a difference there, Paul. Ray Martin asked Mr Howard, 'Why sell a third?' He replied: . .. because we believe that the right policy mix is to sell a third and to retain, as we have, two-thirds in government ownership. I agree with the Prime Minister. I would like to see the whole of Telstra remain in government ownership. Selling off this most prized asset of government is a policy that will have a bad economic impact and a bad impact on my constituents and on constituents throughout Australia. This is not sensible decision making. As Bob MCMullan has already pointed out, Telstra dividends are currently growing at a rate of 15.6 per cent per year. By the year 2002-3, the dividends that the government could have made out of owning Telstra will be greater than the interest saved on public debt. It is a short-term decision, made by a government incapable of any long-term vision. Studies in 1992 in the UK reveal that, in a comparison of nine companies, public sector companies were well ahead on labour productivity gains. The government has also ignored the economic flow-on effect of publicly owned companies operating in the public interest. A privatised Telstra will only be interested in profits. It will not be interested in industry plans and subsidising and promotlocal equipment industry. A privatised Telstra will buy equipment from whichever manufacturing source is cheapest. It will have no compUlsion to buy Australian and this will lead to a loss of Australian jobs. This bill would take the ownership of of Telstra out of the hands of ordinary Australthe ians. Currently we have collective ownership of two-thirds of Telstra. The fact is that Telstra is one of the few telecommunications in the world that does not time. I local calls. The Prime Minister has been very to rule out timed local calls for businesses. Telstra has also not raised the cost of pay phones and continues to provide free information services. But with this bill, that government control will be lost. Telstra has had for a long time what could be best termed a social contract of universal service. In the area of continuing technological advancement within our telecommunications industry, it is utterly vital that the government ensure that these new technologies be distributed equally to all Australians, regardless of wealth and regardless of where they live. We cannot become a nation of communications haves and have nots. The proposal to sell the remaining two-thirds of Telstra makes no sense with regard to the nation's economy, it makes no sense with regard to broader social goals, it makes no sense with regard to employment and it makes no sense with regard to services to our rural communities. It is a cheap election stunt by a very desperate government, and I urge 'the parliament to reject this measure. Motion (by Mr Fahey) agreed to: That the question be now put.
